pull.title: lockedpool: When possible, use madvise to avoid including sensitive information in core dumps
pull.body:
If we're mlocking something, it's because it's sensitive information. Therefore, don't include it in core dump files, ~~and unmap it from forked processes~~.

The return value is not checked because the madvise calls might fail on older kernels as a rule (unsure).

events.body: No apparent reviewer interest, and it seems to break `-daemon` with no obvious solution.

issue.title: Crash dumps from bitcoin-qt contain wallets
issue.body:
On a crash, bitcoin-qt may dump a core file that contains what was in memory at the time of the crash, for debugging purposes.  The problem here is that bitcoin-qt stores the user's wallet.dat unencrypted in memory.  With this information it becomes rather trivial to reconstruct parts of a user's wallet.dat from a .core dump alone.  You can find the wallets within the core file simply by grepping for known parts of a wallet.dat ex: `xxd bitcoin-qt.core | grep "6231 0500"`  With this information you can find the offset of the wallet within the core file, and reconstruct it per a known wallet.dat's length.  Upon reloading the extracted wallet into bitcoin-qt, you'll lose address book information - but balance is retained.  **This has been assigned CVE-2019-15947**.

https://gist.github.com/oxagast/50a121b2df32186e0c48411859d5861b
https://cve.mitre.org/cgi-bin/cvename.cgi?name=CVE-2019-15947

events.message: lockedpool: When possible, use madvise to avoid including sensitive information in core dumps

events.body: Reopened due to renewed interest, and removed the `DONTFORK` part that was broken

rename.from: lockedpool: When possible, use madvise to avoid including sensitive information in core dumps or forked process memory spaces
rename.to: lockedpool: When possible, use madvise to avoid including sensitive information in core dumps

Code review ACK d831831822885717e9841f1ff67c19add566fa45 -- patch looks correct

Please note that I have not verified that the desired end result is achieved.

That should be done before merge :)

ACK d831831822885717e9841f1ff67c19add566fa45

Code review and rebased on master/built/tests/ran bitcoind. The concept appears correct according to `man core`
```
  There are various circumstances in which a core dump file is not produced:

  ... / ...

  In addition, a core dump may exclude part of the address space of the
  process if the madvise(2) MADV_DONTDUMP flag was employed.
```
and implementation correct as per `man madvise`
```
  MADV_DONTDUMP (since Linux 3.4)
    Exclude from a core dump those pages in the range specified by
    addr and length.  This is useful in applications that have
    large areas of memory that are known not to be useful in a
    core dump.  The effect of MADV_DONTDUMP takes precedence over
    the bit mask that is set via the /proc/[pid]/coredump_filter
    file (see core(5)).

  ... / ...

  RETURN VALUE
    On success, madvise() returns zero. 
    On error, it returns -1 and errno is set appropriately.
```
EDIT: tested as described in https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/15600#issuecomment-604144041 below

I checked the manual page for `madvise` and I think the usage is correct.

Not checking the return value is okay in this case because if it fails, there's no problem.  The function is not marked as "warn_unused_result" so this won't result in compiler warnings either.

`/usr/include/x86_64-linux-gnu/sys/mman.h`:
```c++
extern int madvise (void *__addr, size_t __len, int __advice) __THROW;
```

ACK d831831822885717e9841f1ff67c19add566fa45

Agree.

`/usr/include/x86_64-linux-gnu/sys/mman.h`:
```c
#ifdef __USE_MISC
/* Advise the system about particular usage patterns the program follows
   for the region starting at ADDR and extending LEN bytes.  */
extern int madvise (void *__addr, size_t __len, int __advice) __THROW;
#endif
```
I'm going ahead to merge this. Let's add FreeBSD support in a new PR.

issue.title: lockedpool: avoid sensitive data in core files (FreeBSD)
issue.body:
This is a followup to
23991ee53 / https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/15600
to also use madvise(2) on FreeBSD to avoid sensitive data allocated
with secure_allocator ending up in core files in addition to preventing
it from going to the swap.

issue.title: Bitcoin PR tracking
issue.body: The main purpose of this issue is to keep track of Pull Requests on Bitcoin since version 0.19.1 identifying those which make a porting LitecoinZ.

issue.title: Locked memory manager
issue.body:
Add a pool for locked memory chunks, replacing `LockedPageManager`.

Cherry-picked from the following upstream PRs:
- bitcoin/bitcoin#8321
- bitcoin/bitcoin#8753
- bitcoin/bitcoin#9063
- bitcoin/bitcoin#9070
- bitcoin/bitcoin#11385
- bitcoin/bitcoin#12048
  - Excludes change to benchmark.
- bitcoin/bitcoin#15117
- bitcoin/bitcoin#16161
  - Excludes Travis CI changes.
  - Includes change from bitcoin/bitcoin#13163
- bitcoin/bitcoin#15600
- bitcoin/bitcoin#18443
- Assorted small changes from:
  - bitcoin/bitcoin#9233
  - bitcoin/bitcoin#10483
  - bitcoin/bitcoin#10645
  - bitcoin/bitcoin#10969
  - bitcoin/bitcoin#11351
- bitcoin/bitcoin#19111
  - Excludes change to `src/rpc/server.cpp`
- bitcoin/bitcoin#9804
  - Only the commit for `src/key.cpp`
- bitcoin/bitcoin#9598

labels.name: I-SECURITY
labels.description: Problems and improvements related to security.

labels.name: C-upstream-port
labels.description: Category: Changes that are ported from the Bitcoin Core codebase.

issue.title: Patch CVE-2019-15947
issue.body:
Branch: patch-cve-2019-15947

Additional information:
- https://gist.github.com/oxagast/50a121b2df32186e0c48411859d5861b
- https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/issues/16824

Fix in Bitcoin Upstream: https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/15600

issue.title: Potential Wallet Address Book Info Leakage
issue.body:
## Potential Wallet Address Book Info Leakage

Currently, **`dogecoin-qt`** stores `wallet.dat` unencrypted in memory. Upon a crash, it may dump a core file that can be used to reconstruct the user's `wallet.dat`, including the private keys.

This issue is originally reported by oxagast in Bitcoin [issue #16824](https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/issues/16824), and has been assigned CVE-2019-15947.

Specifically,  we can first send a signal to crash **`dogecoin-qt`**, then `grep` for known parts of a `wallet.dat` in the `.core` dump file, e.g., **`xxd dogecoin-qt.core | grep "6231 0500"`**. With this information, you can find the offset of the wallet within the core file, and reconstruct it per a known `wallet.dat`'s length. Upon reloading the extracted wallet into **`dogecoin-qt`**, you'll lose address book information.

We have successfully reproduced this issue on **Dogecoin**, and the screen shot is attached. The terminal on the right side shows the original `wallet.dat` file and the terminal on the left side shows the reconstructed `test.dat`. We can see that they both contain the same address information. 

![dogecoin](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/17737552/140487677-5ff5f4f2-fec5-41d2-8bd0-5eb7eaccdfb8.png)

A possible solution is to use `madvise` [here](https://github.com/dogecoin/dogecoin/blob/master/src/support/lockedpool.cpp#L226-L235) to avoid including sensitive information in core dumps. 

For more information, please check the following pages:

- The original [CVE-2019-15947](https://cve.mitre.org/cgi-bin/cvename.cgi?name=CVE-2019-15947) report.
- Similar fix from Bitcoin [PR #15600](https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/15600).
- The exploit [shell script](https://gist.github.com/oxagast/50a121b2df32186e0c48411859d5861b).

Reported by `de957ad9679f28a38f02f00cc7928bce8fb424882ff060a3c09c32895b1474cc`.

issue.title: Potential Wallet Address Book Info Leakage
issue.body:
## Potential Wallet Address Book Info Leakage

Currently, **`bitcoin-qt`** stores `wallet.dat` unencrypted in memory. Upon a crash, it may dump a core file that can be used to reconstruct the user's `wallet.dat`, including the private keys.

This issue is originally reported by oxagast in Bitcoin [issue #16824](https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/issues/16824), and has been assigned CVE-2019-15947.

Specifically,  we can first send a signal to crash **`bitcoin-qt`**, then `grep` for known parts of a `wallet.dat` in the `.core` dump file, e.g., **`xxd bitcoin-qt.core | grep "6231 0500"`**. With this information, you can find the offset of the wallet within the core file, and reconstruct it per a known `wallet.dat`'s length. Upon reloading the extracted wallet into **`bitcoin-qt`**, you'll lose address book information.

We have successfully reproduced this issue on **Bitcoin Gold**, and the screen shot is attached. The terminal on the right side shows the original `wallet.dat` file and the terminal on the left side shows the reconstructed `test.dat`. We can see that they both contain the same address information. 

![BTCGPU](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/17737552/140502455-0dbdc1d6-38ca-4d37-80c6-ba23538bf86d.png)

A possible solution is to use `madvise` [here](https://github.com/BTCGPU/BTCGPU/blob/master/src/support/lockedpool.cpp#L246-L255) to avoid including sensitive information in core dumps. 

For more information, please check the following pages:

- The original [CVE-2019-15947](https://cve.mitre.org/cgi-bin/cvename.cgi?name=CVE-2019-15947) report.
- Similar fix from Bitcoin [PR #15600](https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/15600).
- The exploit [shell script](https://gist.github.com/oxagast/50a121b2df32186e0c48411859d5861b).

Reported by `de957ad9679f28a38f02f00cc7928bce8fb424882ff060a3c09c32895b1474cc`.

issue.title: Potential Wallet Address Book Info Leakage
issue.body:
## Potential Wallet Address Book Info Leakage

Currently, **`raven-qt`** stores `wallet.dat` unencrypted in memory. Upon a crash, it may dump a core file that can be used to reconstruct the user's `wallet.dat`, including the private keys.

This issue is originally reported by oxagast in Bitcoin [issue #16824](https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/issues/16824), and has been assigned CVE-2019-15947.

Specifically,  we can first send a signal to crash **`raven-qt`**, then `grep` for known parts of a `wallet.dat` in the `.core` dump file, e.g., **`xxd raven-qt.core | grep "6231 0500"`**. With this information, you can find the offset of the wallet within the core file, and reconstruct it per a known `wallet.dat`'s length. Upon reloading the extracted wallet into **`raven-qt`**, you'll lose address book information.

We have successfully reproduced this issue on **Ravencoin**, and the screen shot is attached. The terminal on the right side shows the original `wallet.dat` file and the terminal on the left side shows the reconstructed `test.dat`. We can see that they both contain the same address information. 

![ravencoin](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/17737552/140503409-83b86837-c641-4566-8d98-aed290c8c5ec.png)

A possible solution is to use `madvise` [here](https://github.com/RavenProject/Ravencoin/blob/master/src/support/lockedpool.cpp#L227-L236) to avoid including sensitive information in core dumps. 

For more information, please check the following pages:

- The original [CVE-2019-15947](https://cve.mitre.org/cgi-bin/cvename.cgi?name=CVE-2019-15947) report.
- Similar fix from Bitcoin [PR #15600](https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/15600).
- The exploit [shell script](https://gist.github.com/oxagast/50a121b2df32186e0c48411859d5861b).

Reported by `de957ad9679f28a38f02f00cc7928bce8fb424882ff060a3c09c32895b1474cc`.

issue.title: Potential Wallet Address Book Info Leakage
issue.body:
Since we've sent this by email to info@digibyte.io but got no reply, we submit the same issue here.

## Potential Wallet Address Book Info Leakage

Currently, **`digibyte-qt`** stores `wallet.dat` unencrypted in memory. Upon a crash, it may dump a core file that can be used to reconstruct the user's `wallet.dat`, including the private keys.

This issue is originally reported by oxagast in Bitcoin [issue #16824](https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/issues/16824), and has been assigned CVE-2019-15947.

Specifically,  we can first send a signal to crash **`digibyte-qt`**, then `grep` for known parts of a `wallet.dat` in the `.core` dump file, e.g., **`xxd digibyte-qt.core | grep "6231 0500"`**. With this information, you can find the offset of the wallet within the core file, and reconstruct it per a known `wallet.dat`'s length. Upon reloading the extracted wallet into **`digibyte-qt`**, you'll lose address book information.

We have successfully reproduced this issue on **DigiByte**, and the screen shot is attached. The terminal on the right side shows the original `wallet.dat` file and the terminal on the left side shows the reconstructed `test.dat`. We can see that they both contain the same address information. 

![digibyte](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/17737552/141401989-5659bf4c-7ff9-4f30-a1db-141f763dd00d.png)

A possible solution is to use `madvise` [here](https://github.com/digibyte/digibyte/blob/master/src/support/lockedpool.cpp#L247-L256) to avoid including sensitive information in core dumps. 

For more information, please check the following pages:

- The original [CVE-2019-15947](https://cve.mitre.org/cgi-bin/cvename.cgi?name=CVE-2019-15947) report.
- Similar fix from Bitcoin [PR #15600](https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/15600).
- The exploit [shell script](https://gist.github.com/oxagast/50a121b2df32186e0c48411859d5861b).

Reported by `de957ad9679f28a38f02f00cc7928bce8fb424882ff060a3c09c32895b1474cc`.

issue.title: Potential Wallet Address Book Info Leakage
issue.body:
Since we've sent this by email to contact@litecoin.org but got no reply, we submit the same issue here.

## Potential Wallet Address Book Info Leakage

Currently, **`litecoin-qt`** stores `wallet.dat` unencrypted in memory. Upon a crash, it may dump a core file that can be used to reconstruct the user's `wallet.dat`, including the private keys.

This issue is originally reported by oxagast in Bitcoin [issue #16824](https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/issues/16824), and has been assigned CVE-2019-15947.

Specifically,  we can first send a signal to crash **`litecoin-qt`**, then `grep` for known parts of a `wallet.dat` in the `.core` dump file, e.g., **`xxd litecoin-qt.core | grep "6231 0500"`**. With this information, you can find the offset of the wallet within the core file, and reconstruct it per a known `wallet.dat`'s length. Upon reloading the extracted wallet into **`litecoin-qt`**, you'll lose address book information.

We have successfully reproduced this issue on **Litecoin**, and the screen shot is attached. The terminal on the right side shows the original `wallet.dat` file and the terminal on the left side shows the reconstructed `test.dat`. We can see that they both contain the same address information. 

![litecoin](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/17737552/141402569-da2482b9-ba05-4838-8929-83543a937dc6.png)

A possible solution is to use `madvise` [here](https://github.com/litecoin-project/litecoin/blob/master/src/support/lockedpool.cpp#L242-L254) to avoid including sensitive information in core dumps. 

For more information, please check the following pages:

- The original [CVE-2019-15947](https://cve.mitre.org/cgi-bin/cvename.cgi?name=CVE-2019-15947) report.
- Similar fix from Bitcoin [PR #15600](https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/15600).
- The exploit [shell script](https://gist.github.com/oxagast/50a121b2df32186e0c48411859d5861b).

Reported by `de957ad9679f28a38f02f00cc7928bce8fb424882ff060a3c09c32895b1474cc`.

issue.title: Potential Wallet Address Book Info Leakage
issue.body:
Since we've sent this by the Bug Bounty Program <https://www.dash.org/bug-bounty/> and <infosec@dash.org> but got no reply, we submit the same issue here.
## Potential Wallet Address Book Info Leakage

Currently, **`dash-qt`** stores `wallet.dat` unencrypted in memory. Upon a crash, it may dump a core file that can be used to reconstruct the user's `wallet.dat`, including the private keys.

This issue is originally reported by oxagast in Bitcoin [issue #16824](https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/issues/16824), and has been assigned CVE-2019-15947.

Specifically,  we can first send a signal to crash **`dash-qt`**, then `grep` for known parts of a `wallet.dat` in the `.core` dump file, e.g., **`xxd dash-qt.core | grep "6231 0500"`**. With this information, you can find the offset of the wallet within the core file, and reconstruct it per a known `wallet.dat`'s length. Upon reloading the extracted wallet into **`dash-qt`**, you'll lose address book information.

We have successfully reproduced this issue on **Dash**, and the screen shot is attached. The terminal on the right side shows the original `wallet.dat` file and the terminal on the left side shows the reconstructed `test.dat`. We can see that they both contain the same address information. 

![dash](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/17737552/142573850-0a94f3bd-b0d1-46af-8afb-5c7adb353004.png)

A possible solution is to use `madvise` [here](https://github.com/dashpay/dash/blob/master/src/support/lockedpool.cpp#L250-L259) to avoid including sensitive information in core dumps. 

For more information, please check the following pages:

- The original [CVE-2019-15947](https://cve.mitre.org/cgi-bin/cvename.cgi?name=CVE-2019-15947) report.
- Similar fix from Bitcoin [PR #15600](https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/15600).
- The exploit [shell script](https://gist.github.com/oxagast/50a121b2df32186e0c48411859d5861b).

Reported by `de957ad9679f28a38f02f00cc7928bce8fb424882ff060a3c09c32895b1474cc`.

issue.title: lockedpool: avoid sensitive data in core dumps
issue.body: Backports of bitcoin#15600 and bitcoin#18443 patching [CVE-2019-15947](https://cve.mitre.org/cgi-bin/cvename.cgi?name=CVE-2019-15947).

comments.body:
FreeBSD has the same functionality under a different name `MADV_NOCORE`:

```suggestion
#if defined(MADV_DONTDUMP) // Linux
        madvise(addr, len, MADV_DONTDUMP);
#elif defined(MADV_NOCORE) // FreeBSD
        madvise(addr, len, MADV_NOCORE);
#endif
```
should the return value be used to signal success/failure to the user?
